newsitem.title: INDIA: Delhi shares end lower ahead of settlement close.
newsitem.headline: Delhi shares end lower ahead of settlement close.

text.p: Delhi shares closed lower on Thursday on heavy selling by domestic financial institutions who squared their positions ahead of the end of a settlement period, brokers said.
Brokers said the death of Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping did not affect the trade.
The bourse's benchmark index closed 5.53 points lower at 735.44.
"I think the trade was speculative in nature as most of the players were interested in squaring their positions before the close of the current settlement," said one broker.
Friday is the last day of the current settlement period.
"Increased selling by the domestic financial institutions dampened the market," said Suresh Aggarwal of brokers Jai Mata Securities.
Traders said market was expected to move in narrow ranges over the next few sessions.
"Both buyers and sellers adopted a cautious approach and waited for the government to present the financial budget before staking out fresh claims," said another broker.
Finance Minister P. Chidambaram is due to present the budget 1997/98 (April-March) on February 28.
Reliance Industries ended 3.70 rupees lower at 267.75 on profit-taking coupled with a slowdown in foreign buying, brokers said.
Bajaj Auto fell 14.0 rupees to 928 on selling by foreign institutional investors (FIIs), they said.
Larsen and Toubro shed 1.90 rupees to 240.70.
